output.conclusion: This course provides a solid foundation in thermodynamics, equipping you with the knowledge and skills to analyze and design thermodynamic systems. Further study in specialized areas is encouraged to deepen your understanding.
output.introduction: Welcome to Thermodynamics! This intermediate-level course will explore the fundamental principles governing energy and its transformations. We will delve into the laws of thermodynamics, thermodynamic properties, and their applications in various engineering systems.

chapters.description: Introduction to thermodynamic systems, surroundings, and boundaries. Definition of properties like pressure, temperature, volume, and density. Understanding state, process, and cycle.
Exploring the concept of thermodynamic equilibrium. Discussing different types of equilibrium: thermal, mechanical, and chemical. Introduction to the zeroth law of thermodynamics.
Defining work and heat as energy interactions. Understanding different types of work (e.g., boundary work, shaft work). Sign conventions for work and heat.
Explaining the path dependence of work and heat. Introduction to point functions and path functions. Examples illustrating path dependence.
Statement of the first law of thermodynamics. Conservation of energy principle. Application to closed systems and control volumes.
Defining internal energy and enthalpy as thermodynamic properties. Relationship between internal energy, enthalpy, pressure, and volume. Specific heats.
Introduction to the second law of thermodynamics. Kelvin-Planck and Clausius statements. Reversible and irreversible processes.
Defining entropy as a thermodynamic property. Entropy change for reversible and irreversible processes. The principle of increase of entropy.
Introduction to thermodynamic cycles. Power cycles (e.g., Carnot, Rankine, Otto, Diesel) and refrigeration cycles (e.g., vapor-compression).
Defining thermal efficiency for power cycles and coefficient of performance (COP) for refrigeration cycles. Factors affecting cycle performance.
Introduction to Maxwell relations. Using Maxwell relations to derive thermodynamic property relationships. Clapeyron equation.
Defining ideal gas mixtures. Dalton's law of partial pressures. Amagat's law of additive volumes. Properties of ideal gas mixtures.
